/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
Hello,
I'd like to reiterate on swapping duritong/sysctl to herculesteam/augeasproviders_sysctl. So it would be great to finally swap this module to a better maintained one.

I've seen an older discussion in https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/puppet-ceph/+/495383 where the concern was that there might be conflicts with other modules.
I also see that over the years, duritong/sysctl was removed from other modules: https://review.opendev.org/q/project:%255Eopenstack/puppet-.*+sysctl

There's another option that I see: remove this setting completely. Probably managing system settings shouldn't be a concern of a ceph module at all. There's also a high chance that in any relatively big setup there would be a dedicated module anyway that manages sysctl settings.

I also see a person asking here https://github.com/openstack/puppet-ceph/pull/42 about the current sysctl module, so there's definitely interest to fix this issue.

> Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1
> 
> It might be helpful to explain why the tenant default base job isn't sufficient, or explicitly listing the parent isn't sufficient.

I think the idea was to introduce default behaviour for the jobs local to a project (in this case to the same file) to reduce the need to repeat yourself when a ton of jobs is inheriting from the same parent in one project and another parent in another project.
The tenant default-parent is then on a too big scope since we want it on project level.

> My concerns with this at first glance are that it makes the hierarchy harder to understand (because a user will need to remember to look for pragmas before assuming they have correctly read the job definition).

I don't think it would be too hard to since the pragma is only affecting the current file from what I understood, so it would only set parent=default-parent for any job in the current file that doesn't specify a parent. So it wouldn't change the behaviour for a job defined in a separate file or project (pragma in project A wouldn't affect a job in zuul-jobs).

OK, I just tried this particular example and it didn't work -- the default for hw_pointer_model is 'usbtablet' regardless of the CONF.pointer_model setting in this change [1]. So, if I set CONF.pointer_model = 'ps2mouse' then by default the instance is created with pointer_model = 'usbtablet' and hw_input_bus = None:

2022-02-17 20:10:47,319 DEBUG [nova.virt.libvirt.driver] Found default for hw_cdrom_bus of ide

The previous/current behavior when CONF.pointer_model != 'usbtablet' was/is to not add a pointer device on the guest at all [2].

I'm not 100% sure whether that change in behavior is intentional, I don't see it mentioned in the spec [3]. On one hand it feels like forcing a default hw_pointer_model gives stability, but then at the same time hw_input_bus is None (unstable?).

Any thoughts?

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/800708/4/nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py#917

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: Shouldn't Prometheus look at the exit code or query the job status for a more reliable indicator?

cleaning up the output is fine and welcome, but it's not clear given all the other pods and how things work in these charts that removing -x is the right approach, rightly or wrongly (wrongly, very wrongly) we use that to debug and manage what are extremely fragile poorly tested and debugged script fragments

if the reasoning here being connected to something external which could/should trigger differently is surely more at issue?

No.  Prometheus does not look at exit code or query job status.  Prometheus looks at metrics to determine when alerts need to be fired. If metrics generated by any system is not reliable, then those system needs to be fixed.

There is a ES exporter that queries ES database and counts the number of backup logs generated that indicate a problem.  Those counts are sent to prometheus as metrics.  Prometheus (based on requirements) determines when to fire alert based on the metrics value received over a period of time.  Mariadb backup job needs to generate ONE log if it encounters a problem each time the job is run, not multiple logs when it means the same problem for each failure event.

Thank you for proposing this, and thank you for your patience while I got to reviewing this.

I think the general direction makes a lot of sense and I really want to see keystone support standards that are ubiquitous. Starting with OAuth 2.0 client_credentials and Token Introspection seems like a fantastic first step.

However, I have serious concerns with adding a new token type and I'd like a clarification with how users authenticate and how that authentication is used by the service.

Also, ideally, in the future I'd like to see Keystone support more of OIDC/Auth 2.0, and I'd like to think of how that would extend this is a way that doesn't create conflicting requirements/specifications.

Thank you for your comments.

Please kindly find my replies to each comment.

As for OIDC, I'm not confident to be honest, but considering the situation where keystone behaves as OpenID Provider, I think we can reuse the functions (e.g., the token introspection, token issuing, etc) and DB tables.
At least, it is possible to add an Authorization Code Grant in addition to the Client Credentials Grant defined in this spec.

Let me know if you have any questions regards my comments.

To summarize: I'm still not sure about the exact use case wrt delegation, but perhaps it might be best to use already existing application credentials mechanism, and create an API that allows clients to authentication using already existing application credentials. With that API conforming to the OAuth 2.0 client credentials grant.

I feel strongly that this new API should just respond with normal keystone tokens. And we can introduce an API that takes keystone tokens (whatever they may be) and returns a response conforming to what OAuth 2.0 defines for that API.

Thank you for your comment and my apologies for the late reply.
I basically agree with you, but I'd like to discuss this further.
Please see my comments.

- Added a note that describes the Application Credentials is used as a backend of OAuth2.0 APIs and thus OAuth2.0 users must have permissions to access the Application Credentials APIs.
- Omitted scope. We decided to give up implementing it in the Yoga release as it needs further discussion to integrate the OAuth2.0 scope format into the application credentials one.
- Added DB table consisting of the values that are only available on OAuth2.0.

Also, please check that the current endpoint URLs are appropriate.
If you have a suggestion, please tell me.

According to the discussion in the IRC meeting [1], we'll remove client API.

We feel we have to discuss the necessity of the Token Introspection API.
As we use X-Auth-Token, we can obtain token metadata and the validation result of a token via an existing keystone API.
Thus, we can remove this API as well.

Could you tell me your opinion?


[1] https://meetings.opendev.org/meetings/keystone/2022/keystone.2022-01-11-15.00.log.html

Gage Hugo

specs/keystone/yoga/oauth2-client-creden.message:

In other URLs, they are all "clients", so is it better to unify them?

By service user, do you mean the end-user of a service, or do you mean the service account associated with a service? If the latter, this is something that keystone doesn't know how to define. Service user is just a user that has the role that is configured in keystonemiddleware as the service role, not something that keystone specifies.

I'm sorry for the confusion. 
I'll replace "An Identity API service user," with "The end-users who use Identity API service".

Let me make sure I'm clear on this. 
I assume the use case where an OpenStack user, which is something we can create with `openstack user create` such as `admin`, creates an OAuth2.0 client with `Create Client API`.
I suppose it's not necessary to consider the service account in this case. Am I right?

Let me further elaborate on my confusion.

If the consumer for this authentication type is end-users, this seems to be exactly the use case for application credentials. [0]

Application credentials allow an end-user to delegate a subset of roles (or access to a subset of APIs) to an application that they control.

Currently, you are unable to use application credentials as they are to fulfill your use case, because the NFV specification requires that the mechanism for authenticating users conforms to OAuth 2.0 Client Credentials grant.

Reading through the OAuth 2.0 Client Credentials grant [1], however, I see that the intended consumer for that grant type is confidential clients to access resources they themself own, and not to authenticate on behalf of end users. OAuth.net also mentions that this grant type is to be used outside the context of a user. [2]

The mechanisms that the OAuth 2.0 specification designs for acting on behalf of a user are resource owner password credentials, authorization code, and implicit.

Please tell me more about how Tacker will make use of this, as I'm not familiar with its API. Does the Tacker API have its own user and use that to make requests to other services? Or does it use the credentials of the users that make requests to the Tacker API?

0. https://docs.openstack.org/keystone/latest/user/application_credentials.html
1. https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc6749#section-4.4
2. https://oauth.net/2/grant-types/client-credentials/

> Reading through the OAuth 2.0 Client Credentials grant [1], however, I see that the intended consumer for that grant type is confidential clients to access resources they themself own, and not to authenticate on behalf of end users. OAuth.net also mentions that this grant type is to be used outside the context of a user. [2]

Maybe you're right.
However, the `application credentials` is also a feature that allows a client to behave on behalf of end-users.
Which should we think a correct way, a client must not access any other users' resources or a client can access resources of a user who created the client itself.
Could you please tell me your opinion?

By the way, the OAuth 2.0 Client Credentials grant [1] also says that `Client credentials are used when the client is requesting access to protected resources based on an authorization previously arranged with the authorization server`.
I understand it doesn't mean a client can perform on behalf of users, but we can interpret this sentence as making a client with limited permission doesn't violate OAuth2.0 Client Credentials even if its permission is basically delegated by a user.

> Please tell me more about how Tacker will make use of this, as I'm not familiar with its API. Does the Tacker API have its own user and use that to make requests to other services? Or does it use the credentials of the users that make requests to the Tacker API?

I think the former is correct. 
Tacker uses its own account to make requests to other services and not reuse the user's credential to make requests [1,2].

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/tacker/latest/configuration/sample_config.html
[2] https://github.com/openstack/tacker/blob/master/tacker/context.py#L217-L224

Can you please elaborate more on this? I don't think I'm comfortable with introducing a new token type that is a uuid and allows services to impersonate users. Also, OAuth 2.0 allows for any type of token, any reason to not use fernet or JWT tokens which we already have support for? Also, how would this work with multi-factor authentication, application credentials, trusts, federation (oidc, saml) and other methods of authentication.

Yes, however after the client credential has been created, the user/client/actor can then authenticate without requiring federation/multi-factor auth/etc.

As I described above, we already have a similar credential type, called application credential. 

I think I would prefer to just introduce an API that allows authentication using application credentials, but conforms to the client credentials grant type. Thus clients would provide the application credential id for client id and application credential secret for client secret.

Application credentials already provide mechanism for scoping access. Including delegating a subset of roles, and only delegating a subset of the APIs (via access rules). Both are designed to allow applications to access resource on behalf of a user, and in this way we'd use already existing mechanisms that already provide as the flexibility we need, and only need introduce a conforming API.

In a similar way, instead of creating a new special type of token, this authentication API should just respond with an ordinary keystone token. OAuth 2.0 access tokens don't have any special meaning, outside of what the token introspection API accepts and returns, thus we would only need to introduce a token introspection that accepts keystone tokens and conforms to the OAuth 2.0 specification.

With the above proposals, you don't need to introduce a new credential type, or a new token type. Or fix your specification to a specific token type and refer to clients on the database table.

I really feel strongly that whatever authentication API for clients that we agree on should just return whatever token type keystone is currently configured to return for all authentication types, and we should just create an OAuth 2.0 token introspection API for them.

0. https://docs.openstack.org/keystone/latest/user/application_credentials.html

I understood your concern.
As I thought we should discuss what solution is the best, I'll just change the token type from `uuid`to `fernet` for now.

First of all, in the scenario described here, only users who have already been authenticated create OAuth2.0 clients.
In other words, users might use multi-factor authentication, federation, etc, for the authentication, but the OAuth 2.0 client doesn't, which is what I thought in the first place.
If I'm missing something or you feel the above is not clear in the current spec, please let me know.

In addition, to limit an application's access to APIs, as you may know, OAuth 2.0 provides the mechanism called `scope`. We can use this to safely delegate users' permission to OAuth2.0 clients, i.e., applications.

I basically agree with your suggestion.
We can make a wrapper of the application credentials to provide APIs that conform to the client credentials. 

However, as I described above, if the client credentials should not be a feature to delegate user's roles, the application credentials is not conform to the client credentials.

Also, I'm concerned that the application credentials and the OAuth2.0 client credentials will share the same table.
When a user creates a new client with the OAuth2.0 client credentials, a new application credential is created implicitly.
Would it be acceptable?
I don't think these should be passed in as parameters and instead inferred from the authentication token.

I agree.
I'll remove these parameters in the patchset 8.

See comment above. Tokens should just be normal tokens similar to what keystone would return for any authentication type. Therefore don't introduce a new table in the database for them, or a new field in config.

Can you think of any reason that normal tokens wouldn't work?

As you said, we don't have to specify the token type.
I agree with that.

Thank you for your comment.

I'll fix it in PS13
We need to make sure this gets documented then for using this functionality.
We'll add this warning to the document for OAuth2.0.
I assume the auth for this would still emit a notification, but there may be differences with how keystone currently defines them.
We don't have a plant to add new notification as we'll use existing application credentials codes for the most part. If you think it's better to emit new notification, please let me know.

src/config.yaml.message: this allows injecting whatever key=value into the [ipmi] section, the reported bug only talked about `use_ipmitool_retries`, is there any reason to not expose that as a single option?, the [ipmi] section doesn't have that many possible options that would make (IMO) a generic *-config-flags/params a better path.

Hi Felipe

The bug description says "there is some amount of packet loss between ironic-conductor and BMC" which makes me believe there will be necessity of configuring other ipmi driver configuration parameters command_retry_timeout, min_command_interval when use_ipmitool_retries is false in some deployments.
Given the redfish is gaining up popularity, there will be need for more options for redfish driver sooner or later. So thought instead of having so many options, it will be better to have driver level key=value configuration parameters.

Let me know if you think the charm options should be explicit instead of open ended key-value pairs (where the errors will be discovered late in the deployment).
Updated in PS4 as per Felipe comments

I have tried to clarify by adding a note.

I think it's an attempt to follow something like 

https://writeanswers.royalroads.ca/faq/199070 or
https://grammar.yourdictionary.com/punctuation/when/when-to-italicize.html

For introducing a technical term, but I would argue the term itself is actually "PTR record", so simply italicising the first instance here and removing all the other emphasis of PTR would be preferable. There's a bunch of other uses on this page that should be reevaluated as well.
The formatting still looks weird with this, highlighting the "192" after "dig -x".

For better or worse, every openstack project has documentation that looks like this, eg:
https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/admin/flavors.html#create-a-flavor

The cause is the opening '$', replacing it with '>' removes the highlighting but would put designate out of step with other projects. This probably isn't the right patch to make that change.

As above
Actually there isn't a technical requirement for that zone to exist in designate or even exist at all, so maybe drop this part as the document is way long anyway?
As above, the example itself I'll address in another patch. There's clearly multiple approaches to managing PTR records and the current doc only covers one fairly opinionated method.
In pratice, it would seem very weird to create a full zone for a single PTR record, how about reworking this to create 2.0.192.in-addr.arpa like below directly?

I thought the exact same thing when I reviewed this, but then I realized that shared zones are not yet a thing in designate, so this may be the best/only way to host PTR records in a multi-project environment.
Maybe add a note that the location of the designate based nameserver may vary depending on the installation, this example will work in a simple devstack deployment, but may not in others.
Does anyone actually do this? I likely wouldn't want to promote the use of wildcard records for PTRs.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
Hi Federico why bash agents ? 
Whats wrong with using a python process in the background ? 
the switch from python to bash seems redundant..

Shell is the simpler use case and can work from cirros. I am going to move more logic to the script, to allow using a python script for more advanced agents. The bash one will have very basic features. It would execute only one simple command and write the outputs to two file as it is (stderr and stdout). Eventually it would re-spawn the same command every N seconds and eventually a timeout for a sigle command execution. This is enough for the background ping or for the ncat use cases we do have (even if I have a draft ncat implementation made in python because we are missing it in some overcloud nodes).
All the current logic put in place for the ping would stay, especially the formatting of the command arguments and the output parsing that are performed on the test case framework side (that is the 95% of the code we already have for the ping command).

oh, that makes more sense now , 
but how will you be injecting or executing that command in cirros instances ?

if you just say $PYTHON_PACKAGES you only get the first element

you can do ${PYTHON_PACKAGES[1]} for example it is an array

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
This latest patchset should address most of the concerns brought up in previous comments, the main one being if *at least* one link contains an invalid switch, the condition is logged and the entire port fails to bind. This means none of the respective links (switch ports) are configured.

The bond mode set in the port group is ignored for the purposes of this patch. The original intention was to process *all* port group members and configured= the respective switch ports versus the existing behavior of only configuring the first one.

networking_generic_switch/generic_switch.message: Good point, if we don't know about the switch then we would just exit isntead of check the other ports. Makes sense to cover.
Does it make sense to do this multiple times?
Probably not, since it's the same port w/ multiple defined links
again, continue?
Same as above.
Not sure about this one. I suppose ideally we would validate all switches before configuring any of them.

According to IRC and this spec, https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/ironic-specs/specs/not-implemented/synchronize-events-with-neutron.html, I think the best I could do would be to log the configuration issue as it seems the VM can go ACTIVE despite port binding failure. This would be a little bit more than what exists today. Thoughts?
You are right there. Not configuring the switch would hopefully trigger an investigation however. A half-configured bond is harder to spot.

IMO, it should fail. It seems more likely to be a configuration error than a use case to have one half of a bond managed and one unmanaged. If we do need to support something like that, it should be explicit.
How do you see this validation working, and is it outside the scope of this patch?
When this is continue, processing continues after the error and triggers a traceback at 458 (UnboundLocalError: local variable 'segments' referenced before assignment).
The validation could be limited to the check on whether the switch is in NGS config, and the physnet check on L449. We should check all switches before configuring any of them.

Yes, it makes sense. The question I have is, if the port contains an invalid link (i.e. 1 of the 2 links reference a switch or physnet that isn't configured) what should the action be? Do not configure either link and fail to bind the port? Based on observation, during provisioning, the ports are treated as individuals (w/ a single link). The portgroup (w/ multiple links) is processed post-provision once the OS has been deployed. When should the failure occur?

I'm not sure why segments would be unbound - it doesn't depend on any per-switch info.

Here's some pseudocode for how I see it working:

switches = []
for link in local_link_connection:
    switch = get_switch_device()
    verify_physnets(switch)
    switches.append(switch)

for switch in switches:
    switch.plug_port_to_network()

provisioning_blocks.add_provisioning_component()
context.set_binding()

...

Does that make sense?
Does it make sense to do this multiple times?
I don't see why not.
Probably not, but can be it moved further down outside of the loop?
Does it make sense to do this multiple times?
continue

> Patch Set 4:
> 
> I think the idea was that this is intended more as an element for building a minimal virtual machine image, while coreutils-single is intended for container images (and inherited by way of the containerfile solution).

That is correct. I put the patch here as it's more of a 'mistake' in the image than a problem with test. However, Ian's right that they provide the same thing and are produced from the same sources, just -single is by way of a multicall binary. In that respect, it could be sufficient to alias them in the pkg-map as suggested.
I approved the downstream fix in the opendev nodepool elements. I'm fine with fixing it there.

The problem here is actually in our nodepool/infra-package-needs element, where we are explicitly installing "coreutils" which conflicts with "coreutils-single".  But they both satisfy the coreutils dependency for any other package that needs it -- it's just we're explicitly asking for this version there.

Why not leave the image as-is, and in the pkg-map for infra-package-needs just make coreutils map to empty on rocky so it doesn't get installed?  I don't feel like we need to fix it here in what should be a generic element?

all or any?
if any trait conflict we know its an issue and dont need to check the rest.
with the current mesage format we woudl just append the entire set of traits.

i actully think you dont want  either all or any  and something like this would be better


conflicts = set(any_traits) & set(group.forbidden_traits)
if conflicts: 
  conflicting_traits.append(
      'required%s: (%s)' % (suff, ', '.join(conflicts))

...

i dont know if ^ makes sense but i feel like we really just need to retrun the set of conflicting traits and we shoudl not need to check all of them one by one we should be abel to d a set intersection on them.

if there is an intersetion between required and forbiden then we know its an error so we reprot the conflicts

rather than the end user figuring that out we can tell tehm explcitly.

we spoke about this on irc

i had tought the intent was to block

(T1 or T2) and not T2

which coudl be simplifed to just T1 but that is not the case
we do not want to elimiate any overlap between forbiden traits and requrie traits
we want to block

(t1 or t2) and NOT t1 and not t2

in this case all option in the "any trait" group are blocked by the forbiden traits

we only want to allow cases were at least one of the required traits are not blocked by the forbiden traits. e.g. each group must have at least one allowable required trait for the group to be considerd satisfied.
ack so we now expect normal traits request to be modelled as a list of sets of one element instead of a list of strings
and the in: traits are translated to a set of traits.

Actually this log leve was initially introduced by [1] (and later [2] fixed another misconfiguration at that time). So "3" is used in log_outputs since then.
The logging was directed to file instead of syslog by the change you mentioned, but the level was kept as the same.
 [1] 06c5ab5b3f486eb0f2e507b8cc8cc07cdefacd88
 [2] 387f9d984fdfcbd85eeb23cc0072ad0fae51bf95

The reason why I selected "3" as default was that that was the level 3 was described in default libvirt.conf (and virtlogd.conf) and looked like a good starting point then.
I don't disagree with the reason of this change, but still wondering why we need debug logs by default specifically to libvirt here.
Generally we enable debug by explicily set Debug: true for services and won't enable it by default and I feel having debug "non-default" would be something makes sense. So I leave my +1/-1 here and would like to ask opinions from others. Maybe I miss some understanding about the default behavior in libvirt.
# It logs debug by default with log_filters but without log_outputs ? maybe

I can understand your reasoning, but '3' does not bring any useful logs at all for libvirt–QEMU interactions: meaning you cannot debug anything related to live migration with or without shared storage, and a _range_ of other hypervisor-related things.  (Recall: In the end, a "Nova instance" is a QEMU process — which is doing all the heavy lifting)

Also please note the nuance here: The '1:file" does not enable "debug" for ALL libvirt logs; but only *selective* parts that are critical to debug anything related to libvirt–QEMU interactions.  (This involves a ton of features.)
is that not the intention? I assume we don't want debug logging enabled by default.

As discussed on IRC, no it is not.  The log filters I suggested TripleO to configure have no effect without:

log_outputs="1:file:/var/log/libvirt/libvirtd.log"

For the benefit of others reading: the above does not mean "enable debug filters wholesale".

The '1' only applies for the log filters with '1' here:

log_filters="1:libvirt 1:qemu 1:conf 1:security 3:event 3:json 3:file 3:object 1:util"

Although I myself have been using the above filters for several years; libvirt developers say the above are "quite chatty", so it can have performance impact on some hosts.


IOW, feel free to abandon this patch.  And make users explicitly enable this; or set up some conditional logic to enable the "1:file" if user sets the global debug "Debug=True"

Note the env you checked was running osp-16.1, meaning train. The new virtlogd.log file isn't present in train, apparently. Might be better to check on a master deploy in order to ensure whether this log exists or not.

In master the file should exist though it might be empty without any issues.
I believe having a separated log files per services is useful from log management perspective making virtlogd logs into syslog (or stderr which captured in stdout logs) would be unfriendly for operators.
So personally I would rather change log level if needed than removing it.

Yeah, we can check that separately; hence I put it in the PS:

Just to be clear to reviewers: the "PS" is not related to the important thing this patch is fixing — the standard libvirt log filters, which are crucial for debugging.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
Hello Lior.

I would like to provide a brief explanation why two reviews were created for single patch and few tips about next steps.

Gerrit uses change-id at the end of commit messages to group inbound patches: if appropriate project already has a patch with particular change-id uploaded for review, then pushed patch is used to update existing review and is uploaded as the latest one.

If appropriate project doesn't have a patch with particular change-id uploaded for review yet, then new review is created. That's the reason why a separate review was created for new patch: you have two different Change IDs in the commit message and the latest one didn't match Change-ID of existing review.

I also can see another problems with proposed commit message: it doesn't contain any justification/explanation of this change. I am not sure if you consider this a bug (launchpad bug should exist) or a feature (release note should likely be created), but this is another point about commit message to consider.

Sorry guys for the inconvenience about the duplicate PR (the original was abandoned). 
Again, this change is needed for supporting multipath in the NVMeoF Connector - passing the use_multipath flag also for the Nvme driver.

neutron/common/ovn/constants.py.message:
Maybe worth-adding Depends-On as Sean's comment here suggests:

https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/824833/1/nova/network/neutron.py#669

Sure, will add that.

Your comment reminds me, neutron will most likely expect vf_num from nova to be int. There is at least presence for other numeric values in the binding profile to have that type. And it actually does validation.

Ref:
https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/826099
https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/818420

Worth noting here that we accept "card_serial_number" in binding:profile since we named it that way in Nova but use "board_serial_number" because that's how this serial number is called in the kernel in devlink-info:

https://www.kernel.org/doc/html/latest/networking/devlink/devlink-info.html#devlink-info

An operator specifies this as an external-id 

```
external-ids:ovn-cms-options="board-serial-number"
```

as we document it in 

https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/828103/8/doc/source/admin/ovn/smartnic_dpu.rst#172

So it could still be renamed in Neutron without breakage to have more consistency with Nova.

In case ovn-vif learns some discovery mechanism in the future for extracting devlink info's board_serial_number we'd then need to do the name conversion there.

Yep, the kernel devlink property name is the source of the original choice of `board-serial-number`, I also think the Nova and Neutron specs started out with that.

Have no issue with changing it to match what we ended up with in Nova for consistency.

As you point out Neutron owns both ends of the conversation in defining what the operator puts into the OVN database and what the driver looks for.

Been trying to find out where the confusion came from. The PCI/PCIe specs use the term "add-in card" and specifically the SN VPD field has the following description: "The characters are alphanumeric and represent the unique add-in card Serial Number." I think that's likely the reason why I used the term "card" later because we currently parse the capability directly in Libvirt rather than using devlink. Devlink docs mention PCI VPD but instead call the same field a "board serial number".

So, on the one hand we plug PCIe add-in cards into a (mother)board. On the other hand, every PCIe card has a printed circuit board. Could be a reason why devlink authors chose that.

The main argument I have for consistency in naming at the CMS side (in Nova and Neutron) is that it will be easier to do lookup in the source code.

neutron/plugins/ml2/drivers/ovn/mech_dri.message: can't You here simply pass context.current as "port" parameter?

Looking at the ``PortContext`` definition the ``host`` property does appear to contain some special case handling:

port = context.current, thus only with the context is enough.

In any case, this is not relevant at this point, we can change it later.

The original code passes `context.host` to `self.sb_ovn.get_chassis_data_for_ml2_bind_port()`, so based on that I made the assumption that if we're about the bind the port then the port Dict in `context.current` may not contain up to date information yet, and thus I needed to pass in the PortContext so that the helper could access `context.host`.

I'd be happy to just pass in `context.current` port Dict if I can rely on it containing the required information. I tested this approach on two real systems and it did appear to work.

as ralonsoh wrote (https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/808961/comment/d772a722_1169bbe6/ ) we can change it later, I think we can live with it now

tripleo_ansible/roles/tripleo_nodes_vali.message: Why change the number of packets sent?

If we just send a single ICMP request and it fails, then we need to wait 60 seconds until we re-try. So 5 was just an arbitrary number that I thought would increase our chances of success during the first attempt.
Ah, that seems sensible. Perhaps a note to explain this should be in the commit msg then.

Perhaps this should be an exponential backoff, something like:

      delay: '{{item|int}}'
      loop: '{{ range(1, 10)|map('pow', 2) }}'

This would minimise the delay for a CI environment, but provide a longer wait time for environments that need it.
Good idea. I would hope the CI environments come up and work during the first check, but we can give this a go.

The more I think about this, the more I think we don't want to increase the time it takes for this to fail, if it is actually going to fail. By increasing the count to 5, we increase the chances that we will catch it working earlier. The register and until will make sure the task moves on once we do get a successful ping.

So if it IS actually failed. Then I don't think we want to fail any later.
It seems to me like this would also need the register/until to work properly.

with this we are effectively increasing the time taken by 5... i.e. send 5 ping (with default 1 second delay between each - we can also tweak delay with the -i flag if we wanted to) for each of the 'retries:' 

I think this should be equivalent to increasing the retries and/or delay

[EDIT]: k i see we also set delay (-w) so it will exit (on each retry) after max 10 seconds ... in which case this should not cause any increase in total time taken - we are upper bounding that as before.

placement/lib.py.message:
I got curious about the behavior of parsing forbidden traits for /allocation_candidates and AFAICT it is using lstrip() as well. This is called by placement.lib.dict_by_request() which is called by placement.handlers.list_allocation_candidates().

So it seems like if we fixed the parsing of things like !!!FOO we'd need to do it here too to make the behavior consistent.

And finding this makes me think it would be good to commonize how different APIs parse forbidden traits and make them call the same methods.

Actually my series commonize most of the trait parsing, except parsing traits out of root_required query param, as that param did not get any-trait support so I did not change that code path. But now both the GET A_C and GET RP uses the same parsing logic from placement/utils. So it is better now.

placement/util.py.message:
This is actually a change in API behavior.

In the past the leading '!' was removed with lstrip('!') [1][2]. Therefore placement allowed and striped more than one leading '!'. Now trait[1:] only strips one leading '!' and the rest is parsed as a trait name. 

So in the past !!!FOO meant forbidden FOO, but after this patch it result in HTTP400 as !!FOO is not a valid trait name.


[1] https://github.com/openstack/placement/blob/master/placement/objects/resource_provider.py#L940
[2] https://github.com/openstack/placement/blob/7e0ad4956fa96620d6988b4038e3dc42cd8103fe/placement/lib.py#L50

Yeah, as you mentioned in current code !!FOO is accepted as valid trait and there is no error at the down layer too. So user it this way are getting success case which will be changed to error and break them. It is bad interface but success case for user. We should not change it without microversion. We have ton of such cases in Nova APIs too and we cannot change them just saying "you were not meant to use this interface that way even it is allowed and we have not documented it too". That is main purpose of microversion that we avoid breaking the success case of APIs usage. 

If this end up with error at the end/down layer then yes it become failure case and then we can fix it without microverion.
OK, Then I will replace this with lstrip to keep the legacy behavior.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: a bit of nit here, but this tells a story about when this was encountered but I think the impetus for the change is to ensure that the list running vms action uses the same hostname value as what's provided in the nova.conf file. i.e. its providing consistency with how the hypervisor is configured.

Not entirely. The hypervisors (`nova hypervisor-list`) does not take into account the `host` variable from nova.conf. It always uses fqdn. This change is about consistently receiving fqdn, because when it fails, like for example when `socket.getfqdn()` started returning hostname instead of fqdn, we were unable to match which hypervisor belongs to which nova-compute unit.

I re-run some test just to confirm that my original assumption about hypervisor-list using only fqdn is correct by changing the `host` value in nova.conf to "foo.bar"

Here's the result of `nova service-list`
```
| Id                                   | Binary         | Host    | ...
| d6175b6b-ba83-4dbe-ab2d-3c2624a3c3af | nova-compute   | foo.bar | ...
```

And here's output of `nova hypervisor-list`
```
| ID                                   | Hypervisor hostname | ...
| e495bb98-0714-42fa-b765-2047e67d08ac | juju-4717e3-zaza-59ed604ae779-8.project.serverstack | ...
```
You can see that the hostname of hypervisor was unaffected by change in nova.conf. This change is about consistently getting fqdn.

I can of course re-word the commit message summary to make this more clear. I agree that I probably went on tangent about the circumstances which triggered this change.

I think a rewording of the commit message would be a bit more helpful here to explain it a bit more clearly. You've explained it here quite well and that makes it much more clear than what is in the commit message (for me at least).

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
code looks good and it is a simple change. However, I have a question, why not changing the documentation about what pre-population means, and maintain the current way, i.e., only perform the pre-population upon the first pod creation?

To me, pre-population means we create X ports in the nodes to be more ready. This does not need to happen on namespace creation, and can happen on the first pod creation. In fact, due to the amount of ports created (X ports in all the trunks), perhaps it makes even more needed the current behavior, to ensure we save ports/flows for namespaces that won't needed. Either that or we should do the pre-population per namespace (only tag the namespace we want to pre-populate or something like that)

Adding -1 just to start the discussion

Indeed, that is a good point. I think the solution of adding to the documentation explaining the current approach might be better.

Here are my takes from the testing:
I enabled the population handler, created a Namespace, no KuryrNetwork CR was created as expected, until a Pod got created in the Namespace. Pre-population happened to all hosts except the one the Pod was scheduled (a normal population had already happened to this one). However, I think it's possible that duplicated populations(prepopulation and normal population) happens since we're not locking the force_population[1], it doesn't sound like a big problem though. I'm moving the bz to non blocker[3], let me know if you think otherwise.

Just another thought not on the scope of this patch...
Should we lock pool population for operations like _trigger_return_to_pool[2]?

I left a number of notes. Some of which were only against the Gerrit driver, but I think they apply to the other drivers too.

zuul/driver/gerrit/gerritconnection.py.message: I don't think we have an existing way to make that distinction (and in an open source project, I'm not entirely sure it is a distinction).  The current code is intentionally designed to crash because this case is so severe; I think it's still severe and we absolutely need to track it down.  The system is not operating as designed and may be malfunctioning.  I think "error" is appropriate in that case.

Slight nit that logging this at error level may indicate to operators that these are errors they need to handle. Maybe it should be warning instead or we should indicate "this is a zuul bug please report to the zuul developers" ?
Yes, I believe we are still finding these bugs (and we may make more of them in the future).
Got it. I think I may have misunderstood the severity due to no longer crashing. In that case it isn't just noise in the logs but something that does need to be addressed (one way or another).

Well, it's a change cache... I admit the terminology is a little weird, but the actual change/ref/object should be obvious from the log.  If we were to change anything, we should probably rename it to the 'RefCache' and say the "Ref" wasn't found here.
Yeah, it was the change_key I was thinking of.  Like "Change <ChangeKey something that looks like a branch> not found"

I called it out because I'm not sure log.error will give you code context. And if you end up in this file there are multiple places which could generate this log line. That said you are right that the stringified change_key should give enough context to determine what tripped it.

zuul/driver/gerrit/gerritsource.py.message: Clarification: Gerrit projects don't have projects *for changes*; the other types of entries do use the project name.

Gerrit change keys don't have projects because yes, the project name isn't always available, but moreover, they're not necessary since the number (or maybe eventually someday the change-id-thingy-with-lots-of-tildes) is sufficiently unique.
Why not set the project name here? Is it not available in the change events?

zuul/driver/github/githubconnection.py.message: This is an instance where change_key.newrev and not change.newrev is used.

zuul/driver/github/githubsource.py.message: It's required since every project starts at issue #1.
Unlike Gerrit we do seem to set the project name for github.

zuul/driver/gitlab/gitlabconnection.py.message: This is an instance where change_key.newrev is used and not change.newrev.

zuul/driver/pagure/pagureconnection.py.message: This is an instance where change_key.newrev is used and not change.newrev.

zuul/scheduler.py.message: Just wondering if it would make sense to already send the change key with the trigger events so we don't have to call into the driver again here. It's not an expensive operation, though.

Strictly speaking, if we did that we would send a change reference (json serialized change key) with the event and then construct a change key (python object) from the reference.  It's probably about the same complexity.

zuul/zk/change_cache.py.message:
In general, these values are all intended to be opaque and driver-specific.  I can add that comment, but that isn't something new that's introduced in this change.  The exception is the two new methods below where we centralize knowledge of driver-specific data just because all the drivers use the same format for that data and we can save some duplication.  But those are convenince methods and not required for this class's operation, and I did add a comment there.

Re backwards compat: ChangeKey instances are in-memory python objects.  But they are serialized to json in the reference attribute.  Whenever an object in zk refers to a change, it should use the reference (see comment above).  The reference includes the revision, so this is a change to the serialized format of the change key reference which is written to zk.

It might be worth a comment or docstring update here to indicate that the stable_id and revision avlues may be overloaded by specific implementations. For example Gerrit changes use stable_id for the change number and revision for the patchset number. And revision has the new format for oldrev..newrev.

I'm also wondering how this impacts backward compatibility. The change keys never leave memory right? They belong to a single running process instance? If so maybe we can just change the attributes entirely? I know the commit message indicates this is difficult, but I'm having a hard time understanding why.

Aha that was the piece I was missing (the reference attribute serialization). Maybe a note that these names need to be stable and as a result drivers can overload them as necessary would be worthwile? It isn't critical to have that though.

I tried to be mindful of this and avoid that.  In most of the code I used the pattern:

change.newrew = change_key.newrev
do something with change.newrev

So the change_key.newrev property is only accessed once.

We seem to lookup the newrev (and oldrev potentially) properties multiple times in a row in places that deal with the change keys. Would it make sense to store these values as private attributes on the change key object to avoid doing unnecessary string splits?

The gerrit and git drivers look fine but I noted where github, gitlab, and pagure seem to call this method multiple times.

I'm happy to address this by being specific in the drivers rather than carrying around extra attributes in this object.

deliverables/_independent/validations-li.message:
This seems valid for 'stable/1.5' to me according to documentation [1]:

"upstream: Stable branch names track upstream release names, rather than OpenStack series names."

But i'm not sure whether it's valid to use here, at an independent release.

[1] https://releases.openstack.org/reference/using.html#deliverables-file-schema

Well, our validation won't work without this line, so they can't generate a new branch named (more or less) like a specific tag without this line.

If we remove this line the validation will exit in error and output:

```
1 warnings found
deliverables/_independent/validations-libs.yaml: validate_release_branch_membership: skipping descendant test for independent project, verify branch manually


1 errors found
deliverables/_independent/validations-libs.yaml: validate_stable_branches: stable branches must be named for known series but stable/1.6 was not found in ['austin', 'bexar', 'cactus', 'diablo', 'essex', 'folsom', 'grizzly', 'havana', 'icehouse', 'juno', 'kilo', 'liberty', 'mitaka', 'newton', 'ocata', 'pike', 'queens', 'rocky', 'stein', 'train', 'ussuri', 'victoria', 'wallaby', 'xena', 'yoga']
```

So if we agree to create a new branch for an independent deliverable then we should also agree the adding of this line.

requirements change [1] warrant MINOR version bump, so we need 1.6.0 here. (it's strange that requirements lower bound is moved even lower in a new release, usually it happens in the other direction. anyway, if that works, i'm not against it)

[1] https://zuul.opendev.org/t/openstack/build/07e2e9084012468393751e04a187b8ed/log/tox/list-changes-results.log#210-213

Didn't we say, that stable branch in independent model is not really acceptable?
Besides, i think the stable branch name should represent the location of the branch cut (e.g. stable/1.6 should have 'location: 1.6.0')

Sorry, my bad. I see that there are branch cuts even for independent deliverables.

Anyway, it is still strange for me to cut branch 1.5 from 1.5.1 instead of 1.5.0. (besides, as i commented above, i'd rather bump to version 1.6.0 instead of 1.5.1), but again, maybe it's just me...

Yep,
I'm ok with that, I move it the 1.6.

Thank you guys for the answers.

Ack, actually from this point, we will increase our release tags with 2.x and keep this stable/1.6 for maintenance.
The 1.x version supports a large scope (from py27 to actual current dependencies).

The goal is to evolve like this deliverable for example:
https://github.com/openstack/releases/blob/master/deliverables/_independent/puppet-ceph.yaml

You should be aware that that's won't be possible to create new tag for this deliverable from this new branch.

This is ok for you?
there are other instances of independent deliverables with stable branches. why would it not be acceptable?

okay. Note that even with puppet-ceph all the versions were released well ordered and never a version 2.x was released after the release of the 3.x.

https://opendev.org/openstack/releases/commits/branch/master/deliverables/_independent/puppet-ceph.yaml
i will let mathieu comment on that and if he is happy with the branch location.

Hey Nahim, 

We should have a discussion about this with the wider team; Is your team's concern mainly about keeping the CI running for these older branches? I've always encouraged a proactive backport approach - i.e., not waiting for users to hit the issues, but if you're aware that a bug exists in a prior branch, fix it and make the releases happen. We've been quite successful in keeping deployers/users happy with this approach over the past years. In part, this is successful because of the participation of driver maintainers like yourself - you do the hard work of proposing/qualifying these backports. We maintain the upstream CI for older branches with best effort because we'd like to keep these bugfixes flowing. This process has also made it possible for package maintainers and distributions (like Red Hat) to rely on upstream to land the backports so they can flow seamlessly to their distributions. For example, unless this fix is in stable/train, it will not make it to Red Hat's users/deployers of OSP 16, 16.1 or 16.2. 

Downstream distributions also have a set release cadence. They ship updated packages in intervals spanning a few months - so, if we wait for a user/deployer to report this issue, it causes more pain since they may have to wait for that much longer for upstream to qualify it, and for downstream distributions to patch it, and eventually for them to ship it.

We've had discussions about this topic at PTGs and Summits in the past and have concluded that CI infrastructure cannot/shouldn't be the bottleneck here. If a breakage is insurmountable, we'd have to weigh the risks - would it be possible to do a manual qualification and still get the fix in?
Thanks Nahim, i'll workflow this now..
